messages.text:
for a private registry i have cloned,
on julia 1.6 and 1.7 I am seening
```    Updating git-repo `<mailto:git@gitlab.invenia.ca|git@gitlab.invenia.ca>:invenia/PackageRegistry.git`
SSH host verification: the identity of the server `<http://gitlab.invenia.ca|gitlab.invenia.ca>` does not match its known hosts record. Someone could be trying to man-in-the-middle your connection. It is also possible that the server has changed its key, in which case you should check with the server administrator and if they confirm that the key has been changed, update your known hosts file.```
But not on 1.5
what could be up with that?

elements.text:
for a private registry i have cloned,

Updating git-repo `git@gitlab.invenia.ca:invenia/PackageRegistry.git`
SSH host verification: the identity of the server `gitlab.invenia.ca` does not match its known hosts record. Someone could be trying to man-in-the-middle your connection. It is also possible that the server has changed its key, in which case you should check with the server administrator and if they confirm that the key has been changed, update your known hosts file.

But not on 1.5
what could be up with that?

messages.text:
Hello! We've noticed quite a few people being confused by the "big error dump" that could occur when testing packages e.g.
```(Foo) pkg> test
    Testing Foo
┌ Error: Pkg.Resolve.ResolverError("Unsatisfiable requirements detected...```
and which was fixed by <https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/pull/2232> :tada:
Since this fix is such a big quality of life improvement, i wanted to check if it will be included in Julia 1.6?
Also, is there some way i could have checked this myself (short of building the 1.6 branch)?
(I see it is in nightly, but that's 1.7 now)

elements.text: Hello! We've noticed quite a few people being confused by the "big error dump" that could occur when testing packages e.g.

(Foo) pkg> test
    Testing Foo
┌ Error: Pkg.Resolve.ResolverError("Unsatisfiable requirements detected...

Since this fix is such a big quality of life improvement, i wanted to check if it will be included in Julia 1.6?
Also, is there some way i could have checked this myself (short of building the 1.6 branch)?
(I see it is in nightly, but that's 1.7 now)

messages.text:
This inconsistency trips me up at times
```$ ls

$ JULIA_LOAD_PATH=$PWD julia -E 'Base.active_project()'
nothing

$ JULIA_LOAD_PATH=$PWD/Project.toml julia -E 'Base.active_project()'
"/tmp/tmp.MFtLdqSxfM/Project.toml"

$ julia --project=$PWD -E 'Base.active_project()'
"/tmp/tmp.MFtLdqSxfM/Project.toml"

$ julia --project=$PWD/Project.toml -E 'Base.active_project()'
"/tmp/tmp.MFtLdqSxfM/Project.toml"```
but looks like it is needed to support package directories in load path...

messages.text:
Anyone want to discuss:

There are two solutions to <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/38411>:

One involves   `chmod` every `mkdir` operation to ensure mode `0o777` is actually true  on Windows.

The second is preemptively creating `.julia` in Pkg.jl and ensuring `chmod` is correct.

elements.text:
Anyone want to discuss:

There are two solutions to

is actually true  on Windows.

The second is preemptively creating

messages.text: Which method is preferred?
I'm leaning towards the second stop-gap solution, until the first is more holistically resolved.

elements.text: I'm leaning towards the second stop-gap solution, until the first is more holistically resolved.

messages.text: albeit , we might just want to fix `mkdir` even with a temporary hack.

elements.text: albeit , we might just want to fix

messages.text: would it be reasonable to just follow every mkdir operation on Windows with a `chdir` to fix the permissions to match what UNIX would do?

to fix the permissions to match what UNIX would do?

messages.text: yes that's what my first proposal is.

messages.text: Technically our documentation says we pass 0o777, but we don't actually do that on Windows. So following that operation with `chmod` even if ugly should be the   correct way to go about this.

elements.text: Technically our documentation says we pass 0o777, but we don't actually do that on Windows. So following that operation with
even if ugly should be the   correct way to go about this.

messages.text: all permission stuff seems to be ugly on Windows, so ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
in general, allowing programs to work similarly on all platforms seems good

elements.text: in general, allowing programs to work similarly on all platforms seems good

messages.text: Well I can't comment on whether it's ugly or not, but rather libuv hasn't made a decision on how to implement it in a cross-platform compatible way, which is why it's messy since now every program that relies on libuv has to do it themselves.

elements.text: Well I can't comment on whether it's ugly or not, but rather libuv hasn't made a decision on how to implement it in a cross-platform compatible way, which is why it's messy since now every program that relies on libuv has to do it themselves.

messages.text:
yeah, you can’t trust `HEAD`  to be provided in general.
In theory HTTP 1.1 requires `HEAD` and `GET`  of “general-purpose servers” (<https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616#section-5.1.1>)
but HTTP 1.0 (<https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1945>) doesn’t require it.
and in practice it sometimes isn’t implemented.
I ran into this for DataDeps.jl that wanted to use the header to findout the filename.

elements.text:
to be provided in general.
In theory HTTP 1.1 requires

messages.text: <https://twitter.com/natfriedman/status/1341842180705423360|https://twitter.com/natfriedman/status/1341842180705423360>

So, we used to use Bors on the Pkg.jl repo, and we got rid of it a while back (which I think was a good decision).

At that time, I remember some people (e.g <@U67D54KS8>) pointing out that it would be good to have some option for "auto-merge a PR once tests are passing".

Well, GitHub now has that option built in. Basically, you can tell GitHub "once the required status checks are passing, merge this PR." You can select the merge method (merge, squash, rebase, etc.) on a per-PR basis. You can also cancel an auto-merge at any time.

Would we like to enable this PR on the Pkg.jl repo?

The one caveat is this: in order for this feature to be enabled, we need to mark at least one status check as a "required" status check. Then GitHub will auto-merge once all "required" status checks are green.

More details: <https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/github/collaborating-with-issues-and-pull-requests/automatically-merging-a-pull-request>

elements.text:
So, we used to use Bors on the Pkg.jl repo, and we got rid of it a while back (which I think was a good decision).

At that time, I remember some people (e.g

) pointing out that it would be good to have some option for "auto-merge a PR once tests are passing".

Well, GitHub now has that option built in. Basically, you can tell GitHub "once the required status checks are passing, merge this PR." You can select the merge method (merge, squash, rebase, etc.) on a per-PR basis. You can also cancel an auto-merge at any time.

Would we like to enable this PR on the Pkg.jl repo?

The one caveat is this: in order for this feature to be enabled, we need to mark at least one status check as a "required" status check. Then GitHub will auto-merge once all "required" status checks are green.

More details:

I am sorry, I asked this before but can't find the answer anymore (and stupidly lost the notes where I wrote this down): How could I detect from within a package whether it has been dev'ed in the current project? IIRC it involves `is_tracking_path` (or another "is_tracking" function), but I can't figure it out anymore (and the nefarious usecase here is that I want to use this as a feature flag to enable some experimental features when the package is loaded, which i just don't want regular users to stumble over yet)

(and sorry if this is the wrong place to ask)

messages.text: There is not really an official way of answering that questions. You could hack something together by looking at the current manifest (see `Base.active_project()`).

elements.text: There is not really an official way of answering that questions. You could hack something together by looking at the current manifest (see

messages.text: But from the point of Julia, there isn't really any difference in a package that is devved or not, the only difference is how its location is computed when it is loaded, and that is based on the manifest so it is there you have to look.

elements.text: But from the point of Julia, there isn't really any difference in a package that is devved or not, the only difference is how its location is computed when it is loaded, and that is based on the manifest so it is there you have to look.

messages.text:
I have two sets of changes queued for inclusion into Pkg that should make it in to v1.6:

* The `.pkg/select_artifacts.jl` hook PR, which is here: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/pull/2024>  I need some help in figuring out the best way to get `sandbox()` working properly.

* A new PR that teaches `Pkg` to install packages with respect to a given Julia version.  This is useful for BB to be able to download sets of JLLs targeting a particular Julia version, so that users can build things that e.g. link against `libgmp` and `libjulia` for Julia v1.5.  That’s here: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/pull/2318>

messages.text: Using nightly in VS Code, I frequently see precompile getting stuck with apparently 3 further packages to precompile left, but it doen't say which packages and just freezes with no further output. messages.text: is the following "theory" about the registry format correct: `FLINT_jll = "200.700.0"` means "exactly version 200.700.0", so corresponds to a Project.toml compat entry `=200.700.0` ; while `FLINT_jll = "200.700"` corresponds to `~200.700` i.e. matches any `200.700.x` version?

messages.text: I am currently working on a function which converts a `VersionSpec` into a string suitable for use in Project.toml compat entries, at least when possible, i.e., a (partial) inverse to `semver_spec`. The goal is to use this in BinaryBuilder when generating JLL wrappers; that means it needs to be compatible with Julia 1.0, so I can't output `X - Y` ranges, hence I don't think I'll be able to convert all possible `VersionSpec` values; but that's OK, I believe that in almost all real world use cases the input will be of the form `VersionSpec("1.2")` anyway. I've done some work on it already, but I just was wondering if something like this perhaps already exists somewhere, and thus could safe me some work

When creating a package, I need a specific version of a dependency. I thought I did this successfully when I used `pkg> add ProtoBuf@v0.9.0` and it worked locally with all my tests passing. Building a Docker container using my package instead resolves to `ProtoBuf@v0.10.0`.

How might I specify the package version so it also resolves correctly in Docker?

I don't seem to be able to update a private registry using `1.6-beta1` . I wonder if anyone can advise on where the issue might be and where i should report this?
```(@v1.6) pkg> registry up
    Updating registry at `~/.julia/registries/General`
    Updating registry at `~/.julia/registries/PackageRegistry`
    Updating git-repo `<mailto:git@gitlab.invenia.ca|git@gitlab.invenia.ca>:invenia/PackageRegistry`
SSH host verification: the identity of the server `<http://gitlab.invenia.ca|gitlab.invenia.ca>` does not match its known hosts record. Someone could be trying to man-in-the-middle your connection. It is also possible that the server has changed its key, in which case you should check with the server administrator and if they confirm that the key has been changed, update your known hosts file.

│     — /Users/nick/.julia/registries/PackageRegistry — failed to fetch from repo
└ @ Pkg.Types /Users/julia/src/julia/usr/share/julia/stdlib/v1.6/Pkg/src/Types.jl:1183

julia> VERSION
v"1.6.0-beta1"```
